verses.text: Dead flies make the perfumer’s oil stink; so a little foolishness outweighs wisdom and honor.
verses.comment: Just as tiny things can corrupt what is good, small lapses can undo much wisdom. This echoes the necessity of vigilance and moral purity, a theme later fulfilled in the call for holiness in Christ (see 1 Peter 1:15).

verses.text: The heart of the wise inclines to the right, but the heart of the fool to the left.
verses.comment: Right hand symbolized favor, skill, and righteousness in ancient Israel. Wisdom guides toward what is pleasing to God, while folly leads to destruction. This foreshadows the distinction made by Christ between the sheep and goats (Matt. 25:33).

verses.text: Even when the fool walks along the road, his sense is lacking, and he shows everyone that he is a fool.
verses.comment: Foolishness is evident in one’s actions, not just words. Wisdom should be embodied in daily living, as Christ instructs in Matthew 7:24-26.

verses.text: If a ruler’s anger rises against you, do not leave your post, for calmness can lay great offenses to rest.
verses.comment: Patience and humility can disarm anger, pointing ahead to the ethic of forbearance and peacemaking in the teachings of Jesus.

verses.text: There is an evil I have seen under the sun, something like an error which proceeds from a ruler:
verses.comment: Leadership is prone to error. The author observes that the world’s order often seems reversed, a reality echoed in Christ’s promise to set things right at his second coming.

verses.text: Fools are set in many high places, while the rich sit in humble positions.
verses.comment: The world often exalts the unwise; this reversal is a recurring biblical theme. Christ reverses the fortunes of the humble and the proud (Luke 1:52-53).

verses.text: I have seen slaves riding on horses, and princes walking on foot like slaves.
verses.comment: Again, the order of things is upside down. God’s wisdom often contradicts the world’s wisdom (1 Cor. 1:27).

verses.text: He who digs a pit may fall into it, and whoever breaks through a wall may be bitten by a serpent.
verses.comment: Violence and treachery often turn on the perpetrator. This principle underlines the justice of God’s moral order.

verses.text: Whoever quarries stones may be injured by them, and whoever splits logs may be endangered by them.
verses.comment: All human labor brings risk—an echo of the toil after the Fall (Gen. 3:17-19). Work itself is a place to seek virtue.

verses.text: If the iron is dull and one does not sharpen the edge, more strength is needed, but wisdom brings success.
verses.comment: Proper preparation multiplies results. This hints at the biblical motif that spiritual growth comes through steady formation (see Heb. 5:14).

verses.text: If the snake bites before it is charmed, there is no benefit to the charmer.
verses.comment: Wisdom must be timely applied; otherwise, it is useless. A call for readiness in faith (Matt. 25:13).

verses.text: Words from the mouth of the wise are gracious, but the lips of a fool consume him.
verses.comment: Speech reveals one’s heart. The apostolic teaching urges believers to guard speech, an act also commended in Christ’s teachings (Matt. 12:36).

verses.text: The beginning of his words is foolishness, and the end of his talk is evil madness.
verses.comment: A progression from folly to full-blown wickedness—a warning to be wary of unchecked sin (cf. James 1:15).

verses.text: A fool multiplies words. No one knows what will happen, and who can tell him what will come after him?
verses.comment: Human boasting cannot predict the future. Wisdom recognizes our dependence on God’s providence.

verses.text: The toil of fools wearies them; they do not even know the way to town.
verses.comment: Without true wisdom, even simple tasks are exhausting. True rest is found only in spiritual wisdom, prefiguring Christ’s promise (Matt. 11:28).

verses.text: Woe to you, O land, when your king is a child, and your princes feast in the morning!
verses.comment: Immature leadership brings disorder. Historically, God’s people prayed for wisdom and stable governance, later fulfilled in Christ’s eternal kingship (see Luke 1:33).

verses.text: Blessed are you, O land, when your king is the son of nobles, and your princes eat at the proper time—for strength and not for drunkenness.
verses.comment: Good rulers are temperate and disciplined. Virtue and order bring blessings to the people, reminiscent of pastoral leadership patterns established by Christ (cf. John 10:11).

verses.text: Through laziness, the rafters sag, and through idle hands the house leaks.
verses.comment: Negligence brings ruin. Diligence is a virtue encouraged throughout Scripture and the household is often a metaphor for the community of faith.

verses.text: People prepare bread for laughter, and wine makes life cheerful, but money is the answer for everything.
verses.comment: Material things bring some happiness but cannot satisfy deepest needs. This anticipates the teaching that only spiritual riches endure (Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: Do not curse the king, even in your thoughts, and do not curse the rich even in your bedroom, for a bird of the sky may carry your voice, and what you say may be reported.
verses.comment: Speech matters, even in private. The principle that nothing is truly hidden is reinforced by Christ’s warnings about secret words being made public (Luke 12:3).
